title: Flashlight vs. Candle for Night-Time Spring Clean-Out
vignette: On the eve of an annual spring festival, households traditionally search for forbidden crumbs. One person prefers a modern electric flashlight to the customary wax candle. Should they stick with the candle tradition or use the more practical tool?

options.text: Use a candle as prescribed by tradition.
Use the electric light; it's more effective and avoids dripping wax.

title: Dispose or Sell Forbidden Snacks on Deadline Morning
vignette: Unwanted restricted snacks surface on the final morning before a week-long food ban begins. The owner can burn them quickly or sell them to a neighbor who is not bound by the ban. Which action is correct?

options.text: Destroy them at once, even if inconvenient.
Sell them to a non-participant to avoid waste.

title: Restricted Food Found During the Festival
vignette: Midway through the festival, a forgotten loaf of bread is discovered in a closet.

options.text: Remove and destroy it immediately, despite the holiday disruption.
Declare it nullified mentally and cover it until the festival ends.

title: Enriching Festival Flatbread with Oil
vignette: A commercial bakery plans to add olive oil to produce tastier flatbread required for an upcoming festival. The tradition only specifies flour and water. Is adding an extra ingredient a permissible improvement or a violation of tradition?

options.text: Stick to the traditional recipe of flour and water only.
The oil is fine if the flatbread is still baked quickly and remains unleavened.

title: Working Past Mid-Day on Festival Eve
vignette: A delivery driver's shift ends a few hours after the festival eve mid-day cutoff when certain labors traditionally stop. Must he clock out at noon without pay, or can he finish his run?

options.text: Stop working at midday, even if unpaid, to honor the tradition.
Continue working until the task is done and the shift is over.

title: Joining a Second-Chance Community Meal
vignette: Travel prevented Lena from attending the main community festival meal. She's now home for a smaller, second-chance gathering.

options.text: Attend the second meal to make up for the first.
Skip it; one missed year is not a major issue.

title: Outsider Touching Festival Wine
vignette: A non-observant neighbor passes a ceremonial cup of wine while helping set the table for a traditional meal.

options.text: Discard the wine and refill the cup to maintain ritual purity.
Use it anyway to avoid embarrassing the helpful neighbor.

title: Dough Rested Too Long Before Quick Bake
vignette: Dough for the festival flatbread is left on the counter longer than intended and may have begun to ferment. Should bakers discard it and restart, or may they rush it into the oven if no clear rise is visible?

options.text: Discard the dough and start over to be safe.
Bake it quickly if it still looks flat; avoid waste.

title: Leaving in the Middle of a Group Meal
vignette: During a structured group meal, one person steps outside for a long phone call and then wants to return and continue eating with the group.

options.text: Once he leaves the group, he may not continue eating.
He can return and resume his meal with the group.

title: Renting a Bakery During Grain-Ban Week
vignette: A landlord wants to lease his bread bakery to an unaffiliated tenant for the week when owning leavened grain is banned in his tradition. Is earning rent from that operation allowed or forbidden?

options.text: Renting is forbidden; one cannot benefit from the restricted items.
Allowed, since the tenant is not observant and the landlord does not own the grain.

title: Nullifying Restricted Food Verbally
vignette: Rachel recites the standard formula nullifying ownership of any restricted crumbs but still sees some on the floor.

options.text: The verbal declaration suffices; the crumbs may remain.
She must sweep and remove all visible restricted food.

title: Baking Flatbread with Dough Set Aside
vignette: Dough for flatbread rested longer than expected before baking and may have started to rise.

options.text: Bake it quickly anyway; watch for signs of leavening.
Discard it and start anew to avoid any possibility of leavening.

title: Roasting the Community Lamb with Herbs
vignette: A cook wants to season the ceremonial lamb heavily before roasting it whole for the community meal.

options.text: Roast it plainly without extra flavorings to follow tradition.
Season it; better taste enhances the community experience.

title: Inviting Newcomers to the Community Meal
vignette: Recent immigrants live nearby with limited resources for the festival meal.

options.text: Invite them enthusiastically as part of the community.
Politely decline; the family meal is already large and resources are tight.

title: Finishing the Final Food Portion
vignette: Children are dozing off before the meal is over, and the final symbolic portion of flatbread remains uneaten.

options.text: Wake everyone so each person eats a portion.
One person eats it on behalf of all, and lets the children sleep.
